From Todd Phillips comes a new take on Joker starring Joaquin Phoenix as the iconic Batman villain in a prequel character study where Arthur Fleck (Phoenix) goes from being a broken, down-and-out party clown to the king of chaos in Gotham City.

Arthur is a lonely clown-for-hire with a sick mother he still lives with and a condition prompting him to laugh uncontrollably in the most awkward moments. He dreams of being a stand-up comedian but, between his condition, his increasingly dire work situation and bombshell revelations at home, it becomes harder and harder for him to see the funny side. Especially when the people around Arthur seem hellbent on making his life even more of a living hell. The only bright spark in all this is Arthur's neighbor Sophie (Zazie Beetz) who lives down the hall and is the only one showing him any form of affection. After losing his job, an altercation on the subway ends in bloodshed and things take a turn for the worse. Seeing his hero, talk show host Murray Franklin (Robert De Niro), embarrass him on national television certainly doesn't help things either.

Much has been said about Joker since its release, with some dismissing it as a derivative, simplistic society-made-me-do-it tale while others called it a masterpiece. Admittedly, Joker owes a lot to early Martin Scorsese works like Taxi Driver and King Of Comedy but it's also clear that the casting of Robert De Niro in a major role is no accident: this is a nod to those other grim anti-hero character studies, with a comic book twist. To be fair, the Tim Burton Batman films were pure German Expressionism, X-Men spin-off Logan evoked classic westerns, every comic book movie is derivative in some way, Joker is simply more obvious about what inspired it.

And this point leads me to what I think is the most apt criticism one can make about this film. It does everything it sets out to do extremely well but often in a slightly too obvious or heavy-handed way. From the moody cello-led score (which is admittedly very good) to Arthur's clearly unjust treatment at work and at home, and the recurrent laughter/crying contrast, this is exactly what you'd expect an ant melting under a magnifying glass to look like and there's not much there to be surprised about, except perhaps one twist near the end of the film. 

What Joker lacks in originality, however, it makes up for in sheer competence. Joaquin Phoenix gives another phenomenal performance: his take on the Joker is very different than any we've seen before even if, costume-wise, there's a clear Heath Ledger vibe. His Arthur Fleck is so fragile it makes numerous scenes quite uncomfortable to watch. That skinny, frail frame and arched back, every wrinkle on Phoenix's face is like a scar telling a story, his muted voice with its tone that's always slightly off, the impromptu dances. Arthur, we come to find, was the performance all along and Joker was the painful truth underneath it all.

This isn't the story of a man pushed to his limits by society, though he does use that as a convenient excuse for his wrongdoings and society certainly didn't help. This is a story about how mental illness and physical abuse, if left untreated or misdiagnosed, coupled with financial strain and a rough upbringing, can force people into unsustainable performances of themselves that will inevitably clash with the world around them and how they really feel. Arthur is not just some angry guy who flips out one day because people are mean to him, he's a man with deeply embedded psychological issues that were never addressed, let alone resolved. What little medical help he is provided with is just not good enough and, when even that is taken away from him, what happens next is tragic yet it feels inevitable.

The themes explored in Joker are important and relevant with director Todd Phillips approaching the iconic villain, his emotions and even the Batman comics as a whole, with a lot of respect and attention to detail. While we empathize with Arthur and his tragic life story, his Joker persona is never truly glorified (except by himself) and his crimes are never excused, even with the social unrest brewing in Gotham City providing just the right environment for them. 

A key scene in which he confronts his idol-turned-rival Murray Franklin shows him try to rationalize his behavior and, when that doesn't fly with the audience or Murray himself, he resorts to a senseless act of violence. This proves he is unable to excuse what he's done yet it also facilitates his ascension into a symbol of anarchy and chaos. Ultimately, it's the positive attention given to him by a niche group of rioters willing to adopt this destructive mentality that wins over in the end.

Joker won't be to everyone's taste but it remains a carefully crafted, masterfully acted film with a lot more depth than most comic-book movies and there's something refreshing about seeing an origin story that's about the character but also about bigger, more relatable things. It'll be interesting to see where follow-up projects in the same vein will go from there.

Mikey's Movie Review: Joker (2019)
Todd Phillips' channels the spirit of prime era Martin Scorsese, blurring lines of fantasy and a hyper-reality, to create one of the most emotionally challenging films in recent memory. Arthur Fleck, a lonely clown for hire and aspiring stand-up comedian, is trapped in a city and a world that doesn't care. The everyday apathy and cruelty he endures only antagonizing his worsening mental condition and affliction (he laughs painfully and uncontrollably when confronted, nervous or hurting.). He wants to fit in. He wants to be loved. He wants to be happy. The system has failed him. On reaching breaking point Arthur fights back, beginning a violent chain reaction that will ultimately lead to a catharsis, and a life changing metamorphosis...
While the additional cast are excellent throughout, the film is essentially a one man character study, and Joaquin Phoenix brings Arthur to vivid, heartbreaking life in every scene. It's a testimony to his ability that we more than empathize with the character, that despite his later deplorable actions, we understand and even except his reasons. Both Phillips and Phoenix pushing our expectations and our boundaries. 
As a result Joker will no doubt split regular audiences more used to a softer, purely fantastical approach to comic figures. But DC has long pushed the limits and explored darker, more adult themes in their graphic novels and even animated features. Alan Moore's 'The Killing Joke', Ed Brubaker's 'The Man Who Laughs' and Frank Millers 'The Dark Knight Returns' to name but a few. Since his inception as Batman's No.1 nemesis almost 80 years ago, every generation has reinvented and reinterpreted the Joker to fit with the times. It's telling that in 2019, this is the Joker we need and deserve... 
Mikey's Movie Rating: 5/5* 😎👌

Some movies are ahead of their time. 'Joker' may be the greatest movie to release behind its time. To start, 'Joker' is an almost perfect film if viewed in a vacuum. As far as a realistic story of how one of the most infamous villains ever put to page, the movie is incredible. Particularly influenced by Taxi Driver, 'Joker' thrives on portraying the (admittedly extreme) consequences of a society that undervalues the needed investment in the resources dedicated to the public's mental health. Unfortunately, 'Joker' released in the 'meme' era, and was ultimately subjected to both moral evisceration (some of which was fair), and extremist promotion (an instance of appropriation, a common enough tactic by such group). The acting is fantastic across the board, from Joaquin Phoenix' slowly unraveling Arthur Fleck, to De Niro's exploitative generic late-night show host, the on point acting makes the movie enthralling from start to finish. Controversial, brilliant, a casualty of the culture wars, Joker stands tall next to the other greatest comic book films like Logan and The Dark Knight.

JOKER is cinematic art at it's absolute finest. The direction by Todd Phillips is on point with gorgeous cinematography echoing the work of Darius Khondji in 'se7en' . Low camera angles and wide shots capture Gotham City as I've never seen it, whilst all the time focusing on its lead character. 
  And actor, Joaquin Phoenix deserves all the praise being lauded upon him. His slow burning transition from Arthur Fleck to the titular character is at times, uncomfortable viewing... but what else would we expect it to be?

  Is it fair to judge his performance next to Heath Ledger? Of course, fans and critics will do with every Joker incarnation, past, present and future. 
  But Arthur Fleck is Phoenix's character, and for the little time we view him as the Joker, Ledger fans won't be dissatisfied; it is almost a homage from Phoenix to the late actor and is an accomplishment of the highest standard.

  Does the film warrant it's UK rating of 15? Given the content of the themes explored, I would label the rating as being tame.
  This deserves an 18 restriction.
  The violence we see on screen is not glorified, but brutal and deservedly so. This isn't a movie directed for those easily concerned with social apathy or fears of anarchy. The tone of the film is unsettling and will leave a lasting expression on those who view it... and in closing, isn't that what we, as the audience, expect a movie to do?

A surprisingly well-acted and well-written story, Joker tells the tale of the origin of Batman's greatest nemesis. Joaquin Phoenix is an absolute force, balancing between completely unhinged and grounded simultaneously. His character's story is, obviously, central to the plot- but not in a way that one might expect. Instead of showing us the Joker's early days of crime, viewers are treated to the days even earlier than that when Arthur Fleck (the real name for the infamous villain) struggles with mental illness amid a world that couldn't care less whether he lived or died. And that's where Joker gets its real grit and nuance from- the idea that mental illness is something that can be, and should be, ignored. In its mythos Gotham, as a city, is protected by the Waynes, but the reality is much more bleak. Thomas Wayne (Brett Cullen) runs for Mayor amid his lavish excesses, a race that itself is lavish, while the underbelly of Gotham continues to swell which leads to Joker's thesis argument: That it's the rich and not the poor, downtrodden, and sick of Gotham that are in fact ruining the city. The one percent continues to party while the rest of us are left to rot with no consideration for what that might mean. These pieces set the scene for a more sympathetic and understandable Joker, one whose madness has reason. Phoenix is joined by the always-excellent Zazie Beetz as Sophie, Arthur's neighbor who is perfectly cast and whose story is perfectly paced. The only stumble in this otherwise excellent film is its need to try and shoehorn Bruce Wayne into the project, which it does towards the two-thirds mark. There really isn't any added quality with regard to childhood Bruce, and thankfully the scene doesn't overextend its already lukewarm welcome. Viewers know the universe that they're inhabiting, they don't need such an on-the-nose reminder. Joker still manages to be a force with a relatable angle for the most unrelatable villain in comic book history. Come for Joaquin Phoenix's triumphant performance, but stay for the surprisingly deep message at the core of this "superhero" film.

There's no denying Joker's strengths: Todd Phillips' gritty 1980s New York City is immersive, and Joaquin Phoenix's portrayal of a creepy loner turned maniacal clown is perhaps a career best for him.  That said, it's hard to tell what the point of this movie is.  It goes to pains to show that an uncaring and judgmental society will let down its vulnerable members, risking turning them into monsters.  Yet the tone feels intent on elevating the Joker to some sort of hero or role model -- never mind the fact that he's a violent and unstable murderer, someone ready to drag society down into chaos rather than put in the work to fix its shortcomings.  One wonders if the legions of fanboys with Joker posters hanging on dorm walls will come away thinking the government should expand funding for mental health services, or maybe engage that sad loner on a bus in pleasant conversation, or if they'd rather just pump their fists at the idea of a madman making the world worse.  My bet is on the latter, and for that reason I struggle to find redeeming qualities in this film.

Joker is not your typical comic book film. It is a deep, violent, gritty psychological character study delving into the mind of Arthur Fleck, a mentally ill man who has only ever wanted to make people laugh, to bring colour and joy to the world, but who has been beaten down again and again until he can take no more, and his life takes a downward spiral when he lashes back at his attackers. I love this film This is one of those film that's performances will make the film or break it. The writing, whilst a little rocky in a few places, is still solid throughout, and when it shines, it _really_ shines. This film would not be the same without Joaquin Phoenix's electrifying performance as Arthur Fleck, absolutely outshining everything else in this movie. Phoenix really put his all into the role, to the point that he is no longer playing the Joker. He is the Joker. Phoenix can and does run through depressed, angry, relieved, happy all in a minute, with nothing more than inflections in his voice and his facial expressions. The little details make it all the better. Watch out for a scene I call, "How about another joke, Murray?". That scene is the definition of an Oscar worthy performance. The movie grips you from start to finish, it manages to take a man who kills without remorse and make you feel for him. This movie isn't trying to make you happy, to make you laugh, it wants to make you uncomfortable, scared, angry and it succeeds at all of these from beginning to end.  You will sit down and instantly feel uncomfortable. As the film progresses you will feel sympathetic for Arthur getting beaten down by everyone around him, you will leave feeling empty. This film perfectly embodies the famous quote,
"We all can go insane with just one bad day." If you can handle violence and dark themes and are at all interested in this film, I recommend you trust your instincts and give it a watch as soon as possible. You will not regret it.

Joker Story: The origin tale of the Joker (Joaquin Phoenix) – one of the most iconic villains in comic book history.
Joker Review: Arthur Fleck (Joaquin Phoenix) isn't happy with his life. He struggles to make money as a part-time clown while sharing a rundown apartment with his ailing mom (Frances Conroy). But Arthur lives in a city struck by hard times where a decent, honest living is difficult to come by. He also suffers from a condition that causes him to break into uncontrollable laughter. None of this stops Arthur from dreaming big. He aspires to be a stand-up comedian and attempts to write jokes in his diary. Caught in between it all, Arthur slowly begins to lose his grip on sanity.
It's immediately apparent that this is not your standard comic book fare. Todd Phillips painstakingly constructs the story of a man at his wit's end when pushed beyond his breaking point. Phillips doesn't glorify mental illness but instead makes a compelling case of a deeply disturbed individual struggling to find a coping mechanism in the form of an unhinged alter ego. This also resonates in his gritty vision of Gotham City, a metropolis brought to its knees, and crime is just a way of life. Only the rich and corrupt seem to be unaffected by the mayhem – a pertinent notion in present times. Set in the early 80's, this fictional city is reminiscent of that era with impeccable production and a time-relevant, yet unsettling soundtrack that evokes a constant sense of uneasiness.
Arthur Fleck's gradual descent into madness has a distant parallel to ‘Taxi Driver', also featuring Robert De Niro, so there's a sense of joy for the cinephile to see him here. But, none of the cast holds a candle to Joaquin Phoenix in the titular role, captured by a dedicated and immersive performance. Watching Phoenix disappear into character makes one fear the actor's sanity as he creates his own unique version of the villain. At first, his wiry, awkward frame stumbles to get from one place to the next, but when he eventually transforms, he becomes graceful, resembling an agile dancer. It's simultaneously difficult to watch and yet, impossible to take your eyes off him. If Joaquin Phoenix finally wins an Academy Award for this performance, it will be hard to argue against it. Disturbing and intense, yet undeniably brilliant, this may very well become the definitive origin tale of the Joker.

I saw the (mostly negative) reviews in the big newspapers (NYT, WP, etc) and websites long ago when the movie came out, but I just rewatched it and just wanted to share my two cents. 

Joker has been wildly criticized. A common reason of criticism was the  claim that association between mental illness and violence sends the wrong message about both. 

Personally, I think we tend to overlook subtleties and jump to conclusions that are hard-and-fast, black and white. There's a difference between understanding the reasons behind a behavior and justifying it. Joker does a wonderful job at the former: we get the bigger picture, we see where he is coming from, and have light on the whys behind his actions. 

Yes, Joker does embody the dangerous result of a sick mind and an alienating society, as he says it so well just before killing Murray. His actions, atrocious as they are, do not invalidate this fact. 

Another point refers to the generalization of violent behavior. Obviously, not everyone who is mentally ill is a potential murderer, but everyone who is mentally ill in a society that does not offer support is extra vulnerable to becoming violent, if the wrong combinations are at play. What is art if not a portrait of real life? So the movie does a great job bringing the issue up. 

Again, it is not about justifying  Joker's actions. It's  about understanding and empathizing with the history, but not the action. It's about understanding and about NOT condoning the behavior. I got out of it with so many insights, but I believe these can be lost in the fleeting moment critics fall prey to their own knee-jerk reactions to violence and biases. Joker's actions are understandable given his circumstances, but that doesn't mean they are justified and I think that's the point the movie tried to make. 

I appreciated the acting, the soundtrack and the overall development of the character, ever so slowly but surely, into the maniac. 

Phoenix definitely deserved the Oscar.

Oh god, the Joker. What a masterclass in filmmaking, mood, acting, the dance of the camera, the play of colours and textures and gripping music. Todd Phillips has created something so powerful, so compelling that you can't help at marvel at it as a piece of cinema. Of course this is Joaquin Phoenix's moment of glory, like all his previous acting roles weren't already right up there with the best on screen performances, here he takes it up another notch, maybe to the top notch. The pain and trouble behind his eyes can only be awed at.

I found myself not wanting this film to end, I love the way we intimately see his journey and every incident and knock back, every heart wrenching glimpse of sadness of this tormented soul stoking the fire of not only his demise but also his rise. He made us feel a release through the imagery of killing his own mother, he allowed us in to his hopelessly lost mind where a different kind of sense actually made sense. Phoenix had me glued to the screen, I didn't even want to miss any it to go to the toilet.

There was so much to love about the production design, the bleakness of it, the hardness of it and the use of lighting to give a grade to the film as opposed to it being graded and colour washed heavily after the fact. Really nice use of CGI to augment the city scenes and make it dank and dystopian. The quant mix of old and new technology to create a parallel but alternate universe. None of this seemed out of place, it all went into creating a seamless whole and the viewer was totally sucked into this world and bought into it without question despite the quirkiness and asynchronous nature, no doubt adding to the overall feel of uneasiness and tension.

I think you either get this film or you don't. The message here was clearly one of mental health and not only the health of an individual but the health of a nation as a result of the attitude to the central theme. The slow boiling of the main character with no let up or relapse, just a continual build of tension throughout the piece, leaving you unsure of what could happen next and who was at risk around Fleck as he proceeded to his climatic scene where he finally found his audience, the one he'd been craving his whole life. The crushing sense of defeat too as he went about his daily life added even more and piled on the immense sense of dread and sadness felt by Fleck. The maintenance and the slow build of this film is where the masterful direction of Phillips is so apparent. Forget the politics, this was a huge billboard of a message, shining the light and showing the plight of those who suffer from mental illness no matter how big or small.

The cinematography, man, I couldn't tell you much about it other than it was flawless and unnoticeable - in the best way. There were some lovely scenes that really took your breath but most of the time it just supported the story and that's the most you can ask of your photographer - to assist and add to the story telling and not to detract from it. The sense of darkness and dread I felt were perfectly married with the lighting and mood of the piece. For a tale that was originally a comic book storyline featuring gaudy characters who never really had much character, this shows you what can be achieved in the right hands from such an almost insignificant starting point of reference. Sure, Heath Ledger did a brilliantly good job in the Nolan reboot, but for me, Phoenix wiped the floor with Ledgers performance and elevated it to the stratosphere in The Joker. It takes a special team of people to pull off such a great film and I can't wait to see what these guys get up to next. I hate sequels but I'd love to see more of this story.

Let's start by saying that I did enjoy the movie.  It's a good film, entertaining.  But the hype made me expect more and that just wasn't there.  I'm not in agreement with Dan Kois at Slate who dismisses the movie as "stupid".  There are moments that stretch the line of credulity, but no more so than any other superhero film.  My complaints about the movie center on two main things; plot development and character veracity.  
As to plot, the movie creates a sense of impending doom without ever delivering on the doom.  Knowing that the character would eventually become the mass-murdering "Clown Prince of Crime" is supposed to infuse all of the main character's actions with import.  What the movie doesn't do is build to an inevitable crescendo that resolves itself in tragedy.  In this way the movie is less horrific than it ought to be.  Horror is best when the end product is the result of one action or choice after another - building to an inevitable conclusion.  But in "Joker" there is no inevitability, no lie the character believes, no inciting moment, no complication and development, no buildup of tension leading to an inevitable peak.  Act I is the same as Act II which is the same as Act III in this movie b/c there really is no progress, or attempt to avoid the inevitable, or gradual discovery of the awfulness, or repetition of symbolic metaphors.  There is one big mother of a temper tantrum on live tv which results in some redecorating of the walls of the set but there is no real climax to the story.  In terms of plot, therefore, it's more like watching snow fall off a roof or watching paint dry or watching a pancake slide down a wall; you know it will and when it does... meh.  
In terms of character I have two main disagreements.  
First is an implausibility to the Arthur Fleck character - the guy is a total sad sack whose eventual "transformation" into the Joker is more like one more sucky thing happening to him than it is a moment of horrific inevitability.  It is hard to accept that one person would have so many bad things happen to him; abusive adoptive mother, crappy apartment, loser talents, dead end job, miserable gritty town, hostile and antagonistic neighbors, lousy boss, health issues, bad looks - yeah, your life sucks, dude.  But oddly, even when people seem to have lousy lives they still have humor, friends, moments of joy, insight, access to art or poetry or song or booze - which make life bearable.  Why didn't Fleck have any of this?  Alright, so he's a loser with the ladies, but couldn't he have made a pass at that cute social worker, or maybe struck up a conversation with the gal on the subway after he killed those three dudes?  or learned to play the guitar on the street like John Lee Hooker?  or get drunk at the local with other losers?  Something!  Anything!  It's as though the writers didn't know what normal humans actually do with their run-down lives.  Normal humans eat junk food and get diabetes; binge watch "Game of Thrones" on Netflix; play pool or checkers or Pacman at the local arcade - Something!  Anything! besides washing their Grendelian mother every night.  The character just seems unbelievable.  Indeed, against a hostile world human beings have a startling resilience which takes the most amazing forms; learning to polka dance at the Czech club - collecting spores, molds and fungus - becoming the leading expert on "Doc Savage" comics.  Something!  Anything!  Resistance is not futile!  

Second, Aristotle had it right when he said that horror or tragedy in a character is always strongest when it is the result of the character's own choices & actions.  To choose evil, or even to choose without understanding and thus make a fatal mistake leading to inevitable ruin, is more horrible than simply being the patsy for a violent world.  In "Joker" the maniac is created by a hostile world abusing a poor demented victim.  Arthur Fleck even says this when talking to Murray Franklin (DeNiro)
What do you get...when you cross...a mentally ill loner with a society that abandons him and treats him like trash?  You get what you ******' deserve!
This is too simplistic an equation, I think.  It is as if to say that "society" is to blame – rather than individuals who are evil or good.  Fleck is just "mad as hell and not going to take it anymore!" More to the point is that in terms of art the character is not so horrific because he never CHOOSES to be a monster.  The truly horrific human monsters in literature and in life such as Grendel, Macbeth, Patrick Bateman, Niander Wallace, or John Gacey, Jeffrey Dahmer, Pol Pot, Che Guevara – all choose the role of monster.  Perhaps they justify their actions or perhaps they had horrible things done to them, but their choice remained their own.  The Swansea conference, or the treatments of the kulaks by Stalin, or the flaying of young coeds, or Idi Amin's cannibalistic devouring of his enemies, abuse, child-molestation, random school shootings, slát unwearnum / bát bánlocan / blód édrum dranc / synsnaédum swealh – these are the horrific monsters of human society and all are the result of choice, not mere accident.  As an audience we do not find horror only in the violence they perpetrate but in the CHOICE to commit such violence.  Our horror stems from the knowledge that perhaps we too might make a similar choice.  It would not be so pungent were these events mere accidents of nature, or if they were perpetrated by some unthinking beast.  It is, rather, the willed malice that causes horror to rise in us like some cold Lovecraftian behemoth.  
But Fleck's simpering victimhood doesn't inspire such horror.  He is a pitiable character with his expressions of "I just hope my death make more cents than my life" (poor blighter can't even spell right) and his Hitchcockian mother complex ("She always tells me to smile, and put on a happy face" = pathetic) but he is a victim – a sad skinny puppy cowering in the rain.  Even his name is little more than a fleck even though he is supposed to be Arthurian in his greatness.  When he kills his victims there is even an invitation to rejoice as each one is a bully, a jerk, an abuser deserving of some justice.  In the final murder of Murray Franklin (in an obvious homage to the Frank Miller scene) I had to stifle a little cheer as it seemed so appropriate.  More horror exists in seeing Oedipus come out on stage with his bleeding eyeballs, or watching Sweeney Todd (Len Cariou) suddenly discover who the beggar woman is whom he has just murdered, or watching Bull McCabe (Richard Harris) drive his son over the cliff with the cattle. When Fleck has his final apotheosis on the police car amidst cheering crowds of clown-masked adorers there is little to cheer or be horrified by – it's just… meh.  
In conclusion, I would recommend this movie.  It is a worthy addition to the Batman lore.  Certainly Joaquin Phoenix gives a performance which, though never building in intensity, definitely is deserving of consideration.  The music and camera work are both quite good and there is something of merit in seeing what the movie has to say.  But overall, were I to choose it again, I might enjoy watching pancakes slide down the wall instead.

I'll admit, this was a boring 6/10 or so on my first viewing. But a lot of people suggested watching it again, and it's a solid 9.8/10. Where do I begin? The acting and characters were phenomenal, the writing is airtight, and it tells a believable and compelling story about a man's descent into madness, with messages and themes about how we need to care about and look after people who are mentally ill or disadvantaged. The shots and cinematography are great, the music score and its use are great. A lot of people are complaining that it makes them feel uncomfortable, but that's kind of the point - it's a look into a disturbing life of a man with a mental illness.

Todd Phillips directed this box office hit, based on Bob Kane's DC comics character, creating an origin story around Batman's arch nemesis. Set in early 1980s Gotham, overrun by crime where the streets are littered with garbage, a street clown, Arthur Fleck (Joaquin Phoenix), fantasizes about being a stand-up comedian and appearing on television with his favorite talk show host (Robert De Niro). When his dreams fail, he experiences hallucinations which leads to an outbreak of violence that inspires a countercultural revolution against the wealthy Thomas Wayne (Brett Cullen) in Gotham. This is essentially a Batman movie as if conceived by Scorsese but without the psychological depth or social commentary. Casting De Niro in the movie only makes the comparisons to "Taxi Driver" and "The King of Comedy" even more obvious.  What's most disturbing is that the movie projects an overall feeling of nihilism. Joaquin Phoenix shows, once again, why he is one of the most original and daring of American actors. He takes on one of the most iconic roles and gives it new dimensions. His uncontrollable fits of laughter are indelible. Won Oscars for Best Actor (Joaquin Phoenix) and Original Score. Written by Todd Phillips and Scott Silver. Cinematography is by Lawrence Sher. Music is by Hildur Guonadottir. With Zazie Beetz, Frances Conroy, Shea Whigham, and Bill Camp.

The story is much more focused on classism and inequality than I initially expected due to it mostly being discussed as a representation of mental illness. In my opinion, it manages to simultaneously be both a passable and also hugely inaccurate representation of mental illness. By that I mean Arthur's symptoms of anxiety and his dysfunctional coping mechanisms were somewhat realistic (particularly his shaking, as well as the odd and intrusive nature of his daydreams, which took the form of supportive and loving figures for self-validation). However, his violence is not really due to mental illness or delusion. Rather, it is as a result of his philosophical choices and worldview. 

It left me feeling awful. Because it left me feeling, and I felt its impact ringing in my head for the following days, I rate it highly. Relatively validating, not encouraging. Don't watch when you're feeling down, unless you're okay with feeling worse afterwards.

Reminiscent of a Scorsese film, this psychological thriller does not feel at all like a comic book movie. Many say that Joaquin Phoenix topped Heath Ledgers' Joker. I would not agree because Joaquin Phoenix does something arguably even harder to pull off- he does a great pre-joker; A great Joker back story. The film is more about a potential origin story for the joker and that is something that would be very hard to do right because the joker is already immortalized as the perfect villain. Creating an origin story could ruin the magic and marvel to the joker, but this film adds to it. Instead of merely explaining where the joker came from, like every other comic book superhero movie has done, this film is only giving you a possible idea of what might have happened. It is absolutely true to the essence of the modern joker, and his performance is intimidating, and in the best of ways. Exactly the temperance you'd expect from the Joker in his youth were you to encounter him on the street. There is also some profound commentary on the state of American society that I did not expect from this film, and it made it go above and beyond. The cinematography and side characters are also appropriately grim and dismally comical. I understand why people wouldn't like it because I understand why people don't like the Joker character or these kind of challenging movies, but I say its a masterpiece and a must-see.

I just finished watching Joker and I have to say it was a rather disturbing experience. 

Anyone who knows the history of the character knows that its a very dark and disturbing origin story. Its depicted on the big screen as a combination of mental illness, post-traumatic stress disorder due to childhood abuse, and a traumatic brain injury/neurological disorder. 

The film is also a disturbing depiction and allegory for the current socio-economic and political upheaval going on in our country and in the world in general.  I really couldnt help but think that some marginalized individual is going to take this movie as inspiration to re-create some of the mayhem depicted on the screen. And I think more so with this film that focused on a single character in his dark origin than any of the previous movies in which he was one part of a more obviously almost cartoonish action flick. 

  In any event, I dont think it added anything that we didnt already know or that the DC universe need. It just left me wondering how this has become entertainment and regretting having contributed to its box office. 

  Just my opinion though. Maybe I am becoming the old get off my lawn guy. You might feel differently.

Joker is a film about a man's transformation from the mentally ill loner Arthur Fleck to the widely-known villain Joker. This seems straightforward enough, but there are much deeper messages in this movie that apply not just to this fictional universe, but to our real world. 
Arthur is a man who has been beaten down by not just society but fate itself time and time again. He has been dealt, for lack of a better term, a shit hand and no one in his life seems to truly want to help him. He is a man that truly is alone in society, learning throughout the film how true that statement really is. 
While the actions committed by him are definitely wrong, we understand him and can even somewhat empathize with him (hopefully we can, I may just be weird). Unlike how some people like to suggest, this movie doesn't glorify the violence that Arthur causes. This movie shows how horrible people can be created by the environment they are living in. We are living in a time where we like to blame the violence around us on the insane people who start it. Shootings are happening more than ever, and the insane gunman is responsible for it. 
Of course, it cannot be denied that the gunman is at fault. There is clearly something wrong with the people who do these things. However, much too few people think, "Why is this happening?", "Why are these people doing the things they do, and how can we stop them from doing this?" We see the result of what happens when an at risk individual doesn't get the help he needs in this movie. What we need is a system that can actually help these people. 
The movie Joker differs from other comic book movies because it is not only grounded in reality, but it's messages can be directly applied to our world. People like Arthur Fleck, people who have been brutally beaten by life at every turn need a way to be helped. The rich and successful don't care about these people. These people are viewed as threats instead of who they really are: humans, just like everyone else. We need to create an outlet where these individuals can get the actual support they need, not stuff them with medication and let specialists with their own agendas pretend to care about them. 
Another argument I've seen about this movie is that it has no reason for existing. It shows violence and shows a unique portrayal of a popular character but it has no substance to it. As you can probably tell, I strongly disagree with anyone who believes this, and I truly believe anyone who thinks this completely missed the point of the entire movie.
In conclusion, this movie definitely has substance and doesn't glorify violence in the slightest. This movie brings up an issue in our society that we have been neglecting for far too long. There's a stigma about mentally ill people that we have to get over. People who have been neglected and have nothing left to lose are the most dangerous type of people, and the problem with our society is that we allow people to feel as if they have nothing left to lose. Arthur Fleck is just a person who never got any sign at all that he was needed or loved by society, or anyone for that matter. He is truly, as cliche as this may sound, a product of his environment. You can criticize this movie for being too dark but by doing so you're just dismissing the reality we live in.

Todd Phillips' psychological crime drama Joker (2019) is his most mature feature film yet. Certainly targeting adults only as Joker is brutal in its bloody violence, disturbing in its bleak perspective, depressing in its hopeless attitude, and dark in its somber tone for the entire duration of Joker's quick 122 minute run-time. Jeff Groth's editing cuts quickly from scene to scene without unnecessary explanations, creating a dream sequence feel to many of the Joker's scenes. You are disoriented by Groth's style in a fantastic way as you are forced to focus in on Arthur and experience his journey into madness.

Phillips directs Joker like its a real crime origin story instead of a standard comic book movie. Gone is the facade of green screen everywhere and visual effects propping up lackluster stories, writing, directing, and acting. Phillips outdirects every Marvel and DC film since The Dark Knight back in 2008. Joker easily rivals Christopher Nolan's Batman Begins and The Dark Knight for me. His influences are apparent as Todd Phillips takes his shot at crafting his own Taxi Driver, The King of Comedy, Raging Bull, The Master, and You Were Never Really Here. Phillips pays homage without feeling like he's ripping off classic cinema. Phillips' direction is fascinating in his down to Earth approach with each scene. Joker is like a gritty documentary more than a thriller. He takes an indie drama feel into the blockbuster world of comic book villainy to enthrall into Arthur Fleck's nihilistic world of suffering as he devolves into The Joker. This grounded approach makes Joker feel more mature and nuanced than previous incarnations of The Clown Prince of Crime.

Joker looks incredible, but it's the emotional distress that Joker causes that makes the movie so powerful. Todd Phillips and Scott Silvers' script is an onslaught of misery as Arthur and the audience alike are pelted by cruelty, abuse, murder, outrage, corruption, and sorrow around every dirty corner within Joker. Phillips does question the mindset of the Joker as he's still the villain of the story, but we are following from his point of view. Society is the menace that destroys Arthur Fleck causing him to turn to mass murder, but Joker is still mad and wrong for his killings in the end as he's locked up for his perspective. Phillips gives his character's frame of mind a fair chance and an empathetic viewpoint through his compassionate storytelling that clearly wants audiences to relate to the most notorious comic book villain of all time. Todd Phillips has written and directed one of 2019's finest films hands down!

Furthermore, Lawrence Sher's cinematography is perhaps the most striking aspect to Joker. The stunning images flow like an urban ocean of oppression as the flawed society from Joker's mind is made real. The audience is subjected to all manner of dangerous thinking as the camera often holds on Joker's face in beautiful close-up shots that creates both a surreal view and a realistic depiction of anguish. 

Likewise, Mark Friedberg's production design harks back to the dirty cityscapes of Taxi Driver and the grungy rooms of You Were Never Really Here with a grotesque display of furnishings. I adored Mark Bridges' costume designs. The colorful red and green suit for the Joker's final ascension into crime is cool, playful, and creative. Bridges takes all the most famous designs of clown costumes and subverts into outfits a regular clown for hire might be able to slap together. His realistic designs are the stuff of movie magic!

Similarly, I have to mention the outstanding realistic make-up from Nicki Lederman, who deserves an Oscar for her work in Joker. The colors are vibrant, but her choices create the most haunting clown make-up ever captured on film. I think I now prefer the disgusting verisimilitude of Lederman's make-up to even Heath Ledger's Joker make-up in The Dark Knight. Nicki Lederman's make-up is really that effective!

Joaquin Phoenix gives 2019's most grueling and devastating performance of a broken man. Phoenix is astonishing as Arthur Fleck as his transformation from the muscle bound behemoth in You Were Never Really Here to the near skeletal frame of Fleck. His physicality derives an uncanny effect as you are repulsed by his appearance and strange movements. Yet, you sympathize with his Joker as he endures constant bullying and verbal abuse. The mental strain of society finally gets to him and Phoenix pulls off a more suddenly violent and rage filled Joker that even Heath Ledger's legendary anarchist portrayal. Phoenix allows his Joker to breathe in hopelessness and wallow in Arthur's misery as he cries, screams, and laughs his way into your heart. I felt just awful watching Joker as sequence after sequence emotionally drains you, largely due to Phoenix' moving performance. I could argue Joaquin Phoenix has done the impossible by surpassing Heath Ledger's iconic performance as Joker in Nolan' The Dark Knight as Phoenix is so charismatic, likable, and empathetic in his portrayal. By the end, you recognize the crazy and unpredictable madman from the comics that we have all come to know and love for decades.

Robert De Niro gives his best acting since The Score (2001) and Stone (2010), so that's either 10 or 20 years depending on which film of De Niro's you liked last. His two-faced late night host Murray Franklin perfectly lambastes the shallow interviewing, cheap comedy, and terrible television hosts like Jimmy Fallon, Jimmy Kimmel, James Corden, Johnny Carson, Jay Leno, Ed Sullivan, and especially David Letterman. 

As for the supporting actors in Joker, Brett Cullen's sleazy take on Thomas Wayne is hard to watch, but a great performance. Marc Maron gets a neat cameo too as Ted Marco. Brian Tyree Henry's cameo as a sympathetic Arkham Asylum clerk named Carl is awesome and memorable. Shea Wigham and Bill Camp's detectives add a gravitas and tension to Joker that I appreciate. Leigh Gill's fearful and ridiculed Gary is an impressive role for how few lines he is given. Lastly for the guys, Glenn Fleshler's Randall is a huge jerk and an intriguing performance. He reminds me of Peter Boyle's friendly and gruff fellow cab driver in Taxi Driver, except this time, Fleshler's Randall is irredeemable. 

Frances Conroy gives a touching performance as the fragile mother to Arthur named Penny Fleck. You have to see the warm, likable, and friendly performance from Zazie Beetz as Arthur's love interest Sophie Dumond. Beetz is a kindly face in a cold world.

Hildur Guðnadóttir's score is bombastic and riveting. She composes a memorable sonic underbelly for Gotham and her clown crime lord. I do not want to spoil any of the intense and cool music cues, so I will just say I hope she gets an Oscar nomination, at least, for her Joker score. I love that Todd Phillips chose Cream's "White Room" for Joker's coolest moment during the riot finale. Sadly, it comes at the same time as influential jazz drummer Ginger Baker just passed, so may he rest in peace alongside legendary bassist and singer for Cream: Jack Bruce.

In all, Joker is an inspired psychological indie drama masquerading as a comic book thriller. Todd Phillips directs his greatest film with Joker's unforgettable visuals, gripping storytelling, and nuanced acting. You will regret missing seeing Joker in theaters as the Joker's insanity demands to be witnessed on the big screen. Chaos reigns in Joker's well worth watching world of pain.

My spoiler-free review of Joker is below. This isn't a film for everyone. If you are a comic book nerd, or just enjoy the superhero genre of movies, this might be of interest to you. That said, this film only barely qualifies as a comic book film. It's more like Raging Bull or Dirty Harry minus Harry Callahan.

This film was an excellent stand-alone Joker origin story. The film is set in the late 70s and director Todd Phillips and crew worked hard to pay homage to the 70s style of film making with this film. Right out of the gate, they dug up the old Warner Brothers logo which helps set the tone before the first frame is ever shown. There are a number of scenes where the soundtrack and sound effects evoke a very 70s feel as well. There is even a central scene that, to me, evoked Bernard Goetz (okay, that happened in the '80s but it still felt organic in the film).
Joaquin Phoenix delivers a remarkable performance as Arthur Fleck/Joker. Normally with this genre, you don't get to see a lot of really decent acting on display, especially the type that requires a physical transformation of the actor and a deep shift in their personality. Here Joaquin Phoenix just knocks it out of the park delivering a character that is unsettling, emotionally distributed, creepy, and even a little sad. You are never given the impression that Arthur Fleck is sane, just that he is deeply troubled and his mental issues put those around him ill at ease. To make matters worse for him, the painfully unfunny Arthur dreams of being a standup comic, a plotline that appears in some classic Batman stories. That coupled with a crime-riddled city that seems to be falling apart, a populace that is ready to go to war with the rich, whom they blame for all of the city's issues, and personal issues that enter into spoiler territory, Arthur Fleck's downhill slide toward becoming the Joker is well laid out. None of it has the hackneyed feeling of supervillain origins from earlier Batman films like falling into vats of chemicals or being poisoned by plants. This is a descent from madness to monstrosity that could easily be ripped from today's headlines.
The Gotham 'eat the rich' crowd has shades of the Occupy, Antifa, BLM, and Resist movements, where demonstrations against perceived injustices eventually give way to violence and riots. Arthur is fueled, in part, by this in ways that also border on spoiler territory. However, by the end of the film, it's easy to see why people are concerned about whether this film could be a trigger for violence. It's an excellent film but it's not hard to see the possibility that certain unbalanced individuals might see Joker as a folk hero moreso than a disturbed villain. Unlike films like Falling Down where there are good cops working hard to bring the deranged but slightly sympathetic bad guy down, there is no serious equivalent in this film. There isn't a strong counterbalance to Arthur's madness. Batman does not exist yet.
We are shocked by what he does because we know it's madness. The fear is that the real would be Jokers in our midst don't see the madness as madness. These days, it feels like a legitimate concern, though I don't think that it should stop people from making films like this.
This film holds up a dark mirror to modern society in a few ways. It raises questions about how we treat those with mental illnesses while at the same time making a villain of the mentally ill character. I'm not sure how that will be received by the mental health community but it does serve to generate a little bit of sympathy for Arthur Fleck.
It's not a perfect film, I am not sure that a perfect film exists. Robert DeNiro is miscast as a Johnny Carson like talk show host which is just a bad fit for him. The main 'rich guy' character of Thomas Wayne is a little 2-dimensional, though you could chalk that up to driving the story forward. Some of Arthur's outbursts seem a little forced and there are a few places where you might question how this guy is still walking around free by the end of the film. The film is, perhaps, a bit too dark and gritty; a few moments of genuine levity would be good to break up the darkness. It's also very obvious how the film is going to end by about the halfway point but that's OK. I knew how Titanic was going to end too but I still enjoyed it. I'll probably be seeing it again in the theater.

I'm Not Afraid of The Joker

(Light spoilers for Dark Knight 2008/The Joker 2019.)

In 2008 my wife, several friends and I attended a screening of The Dark Knight. Heath Ledger appeared, made a pencil disappear and won the hearts of audiences everywhere. Including ours. We laughed at his magic trick. We laughed at his psychopathic banter. We laughed when he tried to blow up a hospital and we laughed when he succeeded. He was just so fun to watch. He was fun to quote. Fun to joke about. From Jack Nicholson to Mark Hamill, The Joker has generally been portrayed as an entertaining figure. He does terrible things, but he does them with a morbid sense of humour that captivates audiences.

When I saw the trailer for The Joker, I expected something closer to Dark Knight than Burton's '89 Batman, but I knew we were getting a different take. I knew that the actual meat of this version bore little resemblance to the movies or comics that came before, but I didn't realize it'd be quite this different.

Joaquin Phoenix's Joker is no laughing matter. He isn't entertaining to watch, and that is very much by design.

From the very first scene, there's just something that isn't right about him. He stumbles through a series of disturbing interactions with strangers, neighbours, coworkers and family and it is almost immediately apparent that everyone in his life is counting the seconds until they get to stop talking to him. He is the kind of man you might cross the street to avoid. The movie has a way of making you feel like you yourself are trapped in a room with him and if you're like me, you might find yourself counting the seconds until a scene change offers you some brief sense of relief.

I partially expected that from the trailer, but what I didn't expect was how unrelenting it would be. I thought this was the build up to some more fully realized version of the Joker that would feel more quippy and familiar, but it isn't. At his most fully realized, this Joker is just as uncharismatic, unfunny and unsettling as he was at the start of the movie.

If I understand correctly, the big fear attached to this film is that it might present a version of the Joker who is a 'Patron Saint of Incels', or that it might inspire a mass shooting.

Personally, I don't see it. This Joker doesn't strike me as someone who would identify as an incel at all. And as for a mass shooter? Here's another weird thing by movie standards he doesn't even kill that many people. I think I counted six confirmed kills, with up to three more occurring off-screen. Nine is a fairly modest number, as far as movie murderers, or even Jokers go. And shy of haphazardly lashing out at a society he believes has wronged him, this Joker's kills are targeted at people with whom he has prior relationships (or perceived relationships). If anything, this version of the Joker seems less mass-shootery than Heath Ledger's version (who fired into crowds and blew up a hospital).

It'd seem more likely that he would inspire a serial killer than a mass shooter, since that is what he technically is. Having seen the movie though? I really doubt it. This movie does not glamourize or glorify the violence in any way. The kills aren't staged to look cool, or amusing, or to feel exciting. They're quick and ugly and leave you feeling a little queasy.

While I wouldn't consider other incarnations of The Joker to be aspirational figures, there's often something in there to admire. Generally there's a wit, a style, a sense of humour, a certain level of self-assuredness, or an odd kind of competency. If nothing else, he's got good branding.

Arthur Fleck is charmless, rudderless, unsexy, uncool and about as far from aspirational as you'd ever be likely to get. He certainly is sympathetic in part, but that sympathy only stretches so far, especially given how difficult he is to watch.

In a weird way, I think this movie holds a mirror up to the Joker. It strips him of all frills and pretense and shows us what the character actually is at its core a deranged, dangerous and mentally unstable man whom you would never want to meet.

Basically, if Heath Ledger's Joker is Breaking Bad, Joaquin Phoenix's Joker is Requiem For a Dream.
